overview_of_class: What happens when theatre makers perform in and with communities that are not their own? In this course we will investigate how theatre can build connections between, across, and within communities. We will examine how issues of privilege and oppression inform community-based theatres in the United States, such as Cornerstone Theater, Albany Park Youth Theatre Project, and Theatre of the Oppressed NYC. By the end of the course you will be able to articulate how these companies and others engage the traditions they inherit, and argue for theatre's role in communities that it represents and engages. Like all Theatre 140-2 courses, this class introduces students to university-level research-paper writing that incorporates performance analysis and secondary sources. This course mixes lectures, discussion, and writing to explore methods for theatre history performance critique.

overview_of_class: This course charts different theories of satire in theatre history. By considering the different associations and functions of satire across theatre communities, we come to consider the role of satire in theatre and performance today. Does Longinus linger in late-night? Is Hamilton satire? What are the racial and gender politics of different theories of satire? What are the legacies of theatrical satire on the big and small screen today? We will supplement readings by listening to audio recordings of stand-up and sketch, watching late-night TV shows, and reading and seeing plays. We will also take advantage of all the rich comic and satiric offerings that Chicago has to offer, with an outing to a Chicago comedy event. Through these three productions we will discuss the broader role of the American musical as a vehicle for exploring social issues connected to questions of racial, gender, and sexual identity. overview_of_class: This course focuses on the Spanish author Federico García Lorca and his major plays: The House of Bernarda Alba, Yerma, and Blood Wedding. Through Lorca's work as a playwright, poet, puppeteer, and painter we will investigate theatre as a production process, audience engagement experience, and form of political expression.
